-E4Fu41dwIWneufc22XO4Q.text: Been here around 8 times. I have only ever had the tapas menu sat at the the bar and once sat outside. Really fantastic. The tortilla is absolutely brilliant. I have never had such a good Spanish omlette. I really am not a big omlette fan, but this is really comething special. Get the babaganoush. Bread is complimentary. Also ask for the pimientos de padron. Really tasty. Salty, but for me, they are well seasoned.Just visited here again (27 June 2012) and the waitress/bar tender was really helpful, she went to efforts to explain to me how to make my own babaganoush!Returned again (11 November 2012) I am sorry to say that the same waitress as before was much ruder to me on this occasion. She wouldn't have remembered me, but I remembered her. I was with a younger friend, both students, so we didn't order expensive drinks and so on. A little hard up for cash, she made us feel a little unwelcome. Interesting social experiment really. Have to knock a mark off. Sorry to do it.

CQ0ZushdE-XotJQl7yhQBQ.text: Absolutely my favourite restaurant in London. They cook lamb like no where else I've ever been (don't bother looking at the menu, just order the lamb) and their chocolate and apricot tart is like heaven on a plate. The atmosphere is fun and lively and the staff are friendly. Yes, it is expensive, but the food is such good quality that I think it's worth. It's my must-eat recommendation for anyone coming to London.

T9PW2CkYgnx_wLN6WSGOvA.text: One of my favourite restaurants in London. I like its menus, brilliant service and even decor. We spent there a few nice evening with ladies from work. It is bit pricey but you pay for quality food,buzzing atmosphere and a staff that enjoys what they are doing. I will definitely eat there again.

ejaRlyvdoyhnlIZMmsMCSw.text: My favourite restaurant in London! Everything is yummy, and their wine couplings are fantastic. Try getting a seat in the back room if you fancy a bit more privacy and quiet.

eJV2X1hAbVIQv1o8VBE10w.text: The highlight of Moro is the innovative cooking. Flavours and ingredients are combined in ways you had not thought of before showing the influence of Spain and North Africa. The tapas are fantastic. My partridge was a bit dry, but this could have been a one off problem. Service is friendly but casual. I would recommend.

XfVBFqEYaD-5RkIl1y7Tgw.text: Used to be top 3 restaurants in London for me, but sadly on the decline. Still in a great place (obviously), still really like the staff.... but Tapas offering was average fare (tho babaganoush still to die for)....i visited Tierra Brindisa in Soho recently and to be honest, it puts it to shame. Sad to see and hope Moro pulls its socks up......i'll still go back, once more at least!

UNvjH93jny5LJiKuLvbv_A.text: I had high hopes of Moro given all the great reviews but sadly it did not live up to any of my hopes. Poor service, terrible table near toilets and overpriced food that did not demonstrate any flair or individuality. My companian was vegitarian and only had the one choice of raw slice veg with houmous etcsorry moro 15.00 for this is taking the mickey. Get your act together or your bubble will burst

bJsnCG6lMYVbZocxlTV6ug.text: I had an absolutely melt-in-the-mouth tasty dish of pork when I ate here with a friend recently. I had to stop myself from completely ruining my appetite by gorging on that gorgeous bread with oil and balsamic that serves as the pre-dinner appetiser. We had a rather nice and reasonable Sicilian (I think!) red with our dinner but didn't bother with dessert. We'd booked a table for the 7pm sitting and the waiter was really quite pushy about getting us off the table at 9pm (fair enough but he could have been a little more pleasant about it). Still, this was not enough to put me off potentially eating there again.

4PKgnZu75fm29-W8Y1uNmg.text: Moro is a Spanish restaurant where Spanish and North African elements merge into a choice of tapas, mezze and an inventive South Mediterranean menu. The passionate team behind the place, combined with the use of a traditional wood roast oven make all the difference in creating a fantastic culinary experience. They can cater for private parties of up to 80 people and provide outside seating on the pavement. For an unusual fusion of contnental food with a Spanish or Middle Eastern influence, give Moro a visit..

SC_fxFkiYk3__pnu25VfXQ.text: I really love Moro and couldn't recommend it more to someone who really enjoys good food. This place is really special and the level of care and detail that goes into the food at Moro is such that only a really mean-spirited person could fail to appreciate it. Their sourdough bread which is baked in their own wood fired oven is the best I've ever had (better than St John's and a world above trendy Poilane) and they even make their own vinegar and yoghurt.The menu is always intriguing and is best described as 'well-executed Iberian and North African peasant food' with only the best ingredients. I have eaten there 4 times and had things ranging from wood-fire grilled mutton chop to grilled quail with freekah (like a kind of green, roasted wheat) and the spicing and flavours are always delicious and mouthwatering. The desserts are equally delicious ranging from a cheese course of small, farmhouse Spanish cheeses to delicate almond cakes with orange blossom and creme fraiche.The only negative thing I can say about Moro is that it is probably a victim of its own success and patronised by a lot of people who probably don't really know (or care) what they are eating which makes for a slightly obnoxious and loud (as someone else commented) ambiance. I suspect that this is why the staff can be a little blunt and curt at times but they certainly aren't incompetent. If like me you don't really go out to be pandered to by restaurant staff and are happy so long as you get the food you ordered within a reasonable amount of time then you really shouldn't have any problems here. Do go - it really is wonderful and delicious!

x6civGS-aqZO1zwincUe8Q.text: Being a vegetarian in London is easy. No matter where you go, from Michelin-starred restaurant to run-down pub, there are always options for you. So when I sat down and looked at the menu at Moro, my heart sank a little. There was only one veggie option for lunch, and it was a £14.50 mezze plate. Everything else, despite being non-vegetarian, looked good! I was disappointed, but resigned to my fate. The disappointment didn't last long after that huge plate was set before me. On it were two pieces of crispy flatbread and an assortment of some of the best houmous and roasted vegetables I've ever had. It's been a few weeks since I went there, so I can't remember all the details, just that there were about five or six small salads and dips to spread on my bread and they all tasted very good. One side contained some of the most delicate pomegranate seeds I've ever eaten. The only down-side to this restaurant is that it is so loud. Even though my friends and I were seated near the door, it was so loud in there that we couldn't hear each other talking. For that, I dock Moro one star.

QlVaFvrXrPBiTjJIACnTcA.text: Entirely average and overpriced food with staff that were abrupt to the verge of rudeness (with one exception). We ended up here after playing table football across the road and I wish we'd employed some other selection scheme than choosing the closest place. Not one I'd return to.

pXmNJcCzfy3LRYEWVECtYg.text: We ate here last night for our wedding anniversary after it was recommended by one of our very good friends as probably his favourite restaurant in London right now. As a private member of The Ivy and Soho House to name a few for this to be one of his favourite places to eat meant it had to be good.And boy was it. We made the booking about two weeks ago and was told that the only available time for a sitting would be 6:30-9pm which suited us fine with our working commitments.On arrival we were greeted by some very friendly staff and shown to our table. The instant we sat down and took in the vibe it became apparent how very relaxed and almost bohemian it was. Very Mediterranean indeed.Bread was promptly brought to our table and we kick started the night off with one of their home made lemonades. As its home made you get the choice of fizzy or still, sweet or bitter. We chose fizzy and a bit in the middle for sourness and what we received was heaven in a chalice. I would highly recommend having one.Onto the menu and although I had already perused the menu on their website and sort of made my mind up I was still very open minded. Luckily I was as due to them changing the menu daily there was loads of different items to chose from.For starters my wife went for the pumpkin and labneh fatayer with pine nuts and cinnamon which was a kind of folded bread parcel with mashed pumpkin, pine nuts and cinnamon inside. I only tried a few mouthfuls but the flavours were awesome with the cinnamon dancing around your palette long after you had finished your mouthful. A very well put together dish. I went for the pan fried morcilla, caramelised apple and watercress salad. This was sublime to say the least. The sweetness of the apple combined with the earthiness of the Spanish black pudding left my mouth tingling. Both portion sizes where just right.The wine of choice for our starters was recommended by one of our very knowledgeable waiters. After trying a few we decided to go for the Pittacum which was a very light fresh fruity red which came chilled. As the wine slowly warmed the flavours developed and perhaps even intensified complimenting our starters perfectly.The mains menu proved to be a bit of a challenge for me as out of about eight dishes I wanted to try at least seven of them. Instead I was made to choose one and I wisely chose the wood smoked grouse with panceta migas and caramelised figs. On ordering it I was informed that it was served pink and may contain shot. Well grouse should be served pink and being a wild bird I would question any who had not met its end via a shotgun. Once again the flavours of the ingredients combined perfectly to give this dish je ne sais quoi. With the grouse season being a little slower this year do to a wet spring if its on the menu it should be sampled. This was echoed on many of the other tables and appeared to be a very popular choice last night and rightly so. My wife went for grilled lamb with warm feta and pink fir apple potato salad and tomato, caper and olive salsa. The lamb was served pink and melted in the mouth while the combination of the other flavours was like a firework going off in your mouth. I only had the pleasure of a few mouthfuls as my wife enjoyed it so much I didn't get offered any more than that.The wine we chose for our mains was a Senoiro Amezola, Reserva which was a gorgeous Rioja that once again accompanied our mains perfectly. So perfectly in fact we had two bottles of it.For desert we decided to share ordering rosewater and cardamom ice cream and a yoghurt cake with pistachios and pomegranate. Both of these deserts we're absolutely divine. The flavour of the ice cream was out of this world and the texture of the yoghurt cake just outstanding.At around 8:50pm we were asked if we wouldn't mind moving to the bar area as our table was needed for the next sitting. As we had been talking to the couple sitting at the next to us we asked if there was room for all four of us at the bar. Unfortunately there was not but as cancellation had just come up we were shown to a table of four where we finished the wine over a selection of cheeses and and a freshly made cracker.Every table for both sittings was booked which for a Monday night tells you something. The prices were extremely reasonable we felt for the level of service and the divine food we had the pleasure of eating.I would highly recommend this to anyone able to get a booking?Happy eating London

tcShJqX9a77qH2qanyRMuA.text: Perfect food, friendly staff and no pretence. Love it!

EgwdP14PZf3L6VjSKl9B3A.text: Quite enjoyable overall! A colleague recommended it as I'm staying nearby. The atmosphere is trendy yet comfortable with a moderate noise level. The tapas are good but don't quite reach the level of outstanding. The chocolate-apricot tart though? Divine. The service is excellent - attentive and friendly. All in all a very good call!

fsfb5uXXu2cTe5tpDAjr9w.text: Everytime I have been here the food has been delicious, I love that the menu is printed each day and that there is enough of a selection to have options, but not too many that you have to send the waiter away to have more time to decide. I always manage to try something that I have never had before, last time trying fried chick peas (I would recommend). The service is excellent, the staff all know the menu very well and are happy to chat you through options and recommend if you wish. I also like the relaxed feel that they work hard to maintain, which means that eating here feels luxurious and not rushed. The rosewater and cardamom ice cream is a personal favourite of mine, but it is difficult to recommend meals as they are different each time I go. It is worth booking if in a party or at a busy time, but they are usually really helpful when trying to squeeze people in when you have forgotten to book, or are popping in just in case.

v5Rs6DW0ei04S5frvtP8tA.text: Moro's had a stall at the Dalston Long Table street market, where I was lucky enough to be introduced to their incredible dishes. I had a rich and flavourful chestnut & chorizo soup as well as some sort of risotto with chorizo and almond aioli. Both to die for, and I've been vowing to go to Moro ever since. Really lovely.

X0chTszOS_xFch0KQUvAyw.text: I've been cooking from Sam & Sam Clark's cook books (Moro, Casa Moro, and Moro East) for more than a year now and I've grown slightly obsessed with their techniques, recipes, and tastes.When I recently planned a trip to London, I knew the highlight of my experience would be a long awaited trip to Moro. I googled the location and my friend, who lives in South Kensington, was like - where the f--'s that?! Moro isn't necessarily in the poshest part of London, but the trip was well worth it.  We had to take the tube across town and walk a few blocks to get to the place.When we got in - we stupidly hadn't made reservations, and the Maitre d' (his name was Hugo) was a total ass.  If fate hadn't intervened, we may not have ate at Moro that night.  Hugo told us he had a table for us immediately but we would have to finish within an hour, or we could sit at the bar and wait until after 9:30 pm (we had arrived around 7pm).Incensed, my friend tried to start a fight with Hugo while I played the "I'm so sorry this man is acting this way" card.  Hugo wasn't having it, and we sat at the bar for about an hour and a half.  In that time we finished two bottles of champagne on empty stomachs and made friends with every other waiter, patron, and bar tender around us.  After my friend and Hugo engaged in some nasty staring contests, and after I pleaded with Hugo for a fourth or fifth time, he gave in.  During the entire time there were definitely tables that sat empty for long periods of time until Hugo filled them - I think he was just a jerk.The food was well worth it.  I was excited to see food that was completely reminiscent of the cookbooks, as was the atmosphere of the restaurant.  The design is very "marrakesh meets barcelona" with hard wood, bright blues, tiles, gem tones, you name it.  The bathrooms are exceptionally cute.I don't remember exactly what we ate - something that had pomegranate seeds, pine nuts, couscous, and meat.  But it was delicious.  We had an olive oil cake for dinner - not sweet at all, but I loved it.I couldn't have been happier finally eating at Moro.  If I do move to London in the future I will make it out to Moro at least once every month or so.

DlsnsrsR189AiAaT6xietg.text: Wonderful flavours! Have wanted to try Moro for a while just not had the chance. But a client recently picked Moro from a list of three restaurants I sent him. We both enjoyed every one of the three courses we had. Each was unusual full of flavour. Favourite dish: village soup. And service was great - attentive but unobtrusive. Can't wait to go back.

90Mav75Qyqv2qRYKCxrTEg.text: Wow, truly special food. Here they selected a perfect red wine for me. That may not sound like a feat, but here's the second part, I was eating sea bass. Not at all harsh, it ain't heavy, its just food to perfection that really takes the flavors endemic in southern spain/morocco and translates them to something truly unique. You have to try to believe, really culinary creation in a very cool and lively setting appropriate for all.

XeLDUC_zLIdbPTVSDLYC4A.text: Everything I'd say about Moro has been said before; the food can be fantastic (although my roasted mackerel and koshary, which was heavenly, sat heavily on my stomach until midday. And at £17.50 it was extraordinarily overpriced, following a single scallop that cost £8.50. What makes it so isn't that the raw ingredients cost so little, but the 'extras' that add the value - great service, ambience, something 'special'- simply aren't always there. We ate at the bar - and the barman was polite enough, although dispensed drink and food with all the charm and warmth of a mortician; ie someone who's not too bothered about customer experience. The best, best thing about Moro is the yoghurt cake, which is delicious; chips of pistachio nuts, pomegranate seeds; wonderful. So go for that, and have a chop around the corner first at the Quality Chop House.

jv-PDlh9votp8y6GJU7W6w.text: Amazing food right in Clerkenwell.  Easily got a reservation for 7, which they happily adjusted.  I think everyone enjoyed their meat and fish dishes more than I did the only vegetarian main on the menu (a sampler plate, the "mixed vegetable mezze" -- try harder, please?), but it was quite good.  And dessert was absolutely outstanding: The apricot-chocolate torte was out of control, so much that I had to cover my face so as not to be indecent about my enjoyment of it.  And DO NOT MISS the acorn liquer!  Outstanding.

Zga-zdkzG4f8P-FqMYDhDg.text: I first heard of Moro from their fabulous cookbook that my flatmate has, great recipes in there, love it. I live in Edinburgh and having a weekend in London recently, I took the opportunity to go to Moro (at last!) and was not dissappointed! My boyfriend and I went along and had a fabulous 3 course meal with all the trimmings (great Spanish wine, matched dessert wines, coffee). The highlights for us were, well everything really but if I have to pick a couple of things then the Oak smoked lamb, cooked to perfection and not too smokey mmmmm and the cheeseboard was heaven on a plate. I wanted the meal to last forever and wished I lived in London so I could go more often. Please Moro come to Edinburgh!!

XDBytgDZ4aoe-9rYFIDJEQ.text: Very good but I don't think Moro lives up to the hype. I prefer eating tapas at the bar to Moro's full-on sit down experience. I always have to admit that I love their roast lamb lunches served on Exmouth Market for five quid!!! from Wednesday-Friday (maybe more days in the summer?). So, what's not to love? I don't know. It's pricey and service is kinda snooty. It's ridiculously difficult to even make a reservation for this place too! But I have to say, if I were just reviewing a leisurely lunch at the bar or grabbing the roast lamb lunch on the street, I'd give 5 stars.

VUjGFkdNx8f9C3i-AY4ROQ.text: i always wanted to come here while living in london but never got a chance, so since i'm visiting, a group of us decided to come here for dinner last night.  i love the vibe of this place.  we started w/ some tapas and wine and moved onto entrees.  i had the tuna, and it was delicious.  everything here is delicious, even the bread, olive oil, and salt.  hummus was also spectacular.

qn16-7D9_VAj_S7iEtm99Q.text: Nice food, shame it's not larger.

CiKNW2lmni_jPruLGCHm8w.text: Moro is a fantastic Spanish tapas restaurant. The location is quite random and reservations are an absolute must, but aside from this: the food is delicious, unique and flavorful. It is romantic, but has a relaxed atmosphere which also makes it great for a large group of friends. The baba ghanoush & raisin ice cream with sherry will change your life - not to be missed.

XiuUImRgY8ZFemi90gP3rA.text: A really great restaurant. Hats off to Sam and Sam. Serious research , great ingredients and fantastic food beautifully executed covering recipes from southern Spain to Syria via North Africa. Moro is an institution.

3-Xos8gsetpbnmecDaHm2Q.text: Yes the foods good, but who in the real world has £71 for a lunch for 2 and that's including just their cheapest wine. The place is noisy, they should get someone in to break the ceiling up with some kind of baffles. As for the decor it needs ripping out and starting again, the walls are lumpy and badly painted, with the money they are making they should be able to afford to do that.To summarize your spending lots of money in a noisy, trashy looking place, but a lot of people do it, so something must be right.

VLVGRCGk85npCuKSUkIKIA.text: wood oven...fresh fish...need i say more...

ZVC_3tpGMeYoAmCbsTByQw.text: I was invited to Moro for a business meal as I'm about to start a new job. This was the choice of my new boss, and what a choice it was! The restaurant is cosy yet fashionable and has a quite rustic feel. The exposed kitchen at the back of the restaurant isn't intrusive and adds to the atmosphere. Our table was situated at the back and tucked around a corner, there was heaps of natural light from the skylight which was unusual in this normally quite dark restaurant. We had some bread and mezze to start. The bread is absolutely amazing all hand made on site and when dipped in fantastic oils and salt and pepper, truly divine. I tried some of the mezze bits and pieces which included a spectacular Spanish omlette type thing. For starter I had broad beans with coriander and cous cous. It was really light and a nice fresh course to start the proper eating with. For main I had the whole Bream. The fish tasted fantastic and, on the whole, every bit of delicious white meat slid off the bones. The beetroot condiment that accompanied it was also really good and the bright green (coriander) sauce was also a big hit. For desert I tried the legendary pistachio and yogurt cake, kind of like a weird cross between a cheesecake and a mushy mess. It did, of course, taste amazing. I also tried some of the Alfonso mango which was unlike any other mango I've ever tasted. Top notch!!! All the wine we had was excellent, it's all Spanish and really tasty. Thank god someone else was picking up the bill - this place isn't cheap, but well worth the money. A fantastic restaurant, unpretentious and committed to serving amazing food. Book early - this place is going to be full - especially as it's just won the Observer Food Awards Restaurant of the Year. And well deserved too. Five stars!!!

sJCUCbMYjG7loKjhnoKcuQ.text: It's always exciting to have a table in this ever-popular restaurant but this Gibbon was disappointed. They're stingy with the bread and super-stingy with the portions. Two courses barely touch the sides. Although the flavours are excellent, my squid starter was absolutely over-cooked. That's unforgivable when small piece with a bit of rocket salad comes in at £8.50. The main course was tiny. You know when you have to slow down to a virtual stop just so you don't clear your plate in two minutes? That's what you'll need to do here. Service could do with being less snooty, although it was perfectly efficient. Won't be returning as it's quite simply overpriced - the food is good, but they need to be more generous with the portions and accept they aren't quite a fine dining establishment (nor would people want them to be).

ZQyI5PdLtUJfrrq0On1Z0A.text: Wasn't blown away,  especially given the price. Our food was generally good but not outstanding. The bread however was beautiful and definitely worth sampling. Service was extremely friendly and attentive.

tS59WEqroxr5rJmUhcLA0Q.text: Sometimes London gives you a day packed with sunshine and puffy clouds.  When this happens it's necessary to spend every second possible outside.  Saturday was brimming with summer so I went on a quest for tapas and ended up grazing at one of Moro's outdoor tables during lunchtime.  And it was perfect.  The first thing on the table was hummus and I didn't want it to end.  I don't know what they put in it to make it taste so smokey and earthy.  It was probably magic dust.  While flipping through the weekend newspaper I nibbled on frutos secos (expensive corn nuts), pimentos de padron (oh, sea salt, I love you so), manchego with membrillo, and some of the best gazpatcho I've ever put in my mouth.  I believe there were hard bits of ham floating on top.  I'm hungry just thinking about it.  Dessert was a cheese plate that came with a flaky tortilla.  I have to give it five stars because I wouldn't have changed a single thing.

sCgJMTOpmHYDe7QI2DSzYQ.text: This review is of the Moro stall setup during weekday lunch at Exmouth Market.  I think it only serves 1 dish a day.  I had the chicken kebab and it was fantastic.  I wasn't expecting the couscous but it definitely added a nice texture to the meal.  £5 for a very generous lunch portion.

photos.caption: Photo of Moro Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Moro's stall - chicken kebab

8NMFLG5NxNHhYhM6X0R4Gg.text: Sadly disappointing, went there this evening for my birthday, 12.5% service charge is now on the menu, service should be factored into the price, gratuities to go to staff, sorry but no thanksOur first time going there for a few years and when we left the staff attitude was ' like we give a sh*t, there are plenty of mug punters who'll pay these prices'

_hM1KzLyrIUvBjc8ErDJBw.text: Apart from a smaller-than-expected appetiser (the Sea Urchin was perhaps the most absurdly tiny dish that I've ever ordered in a restaurant) and a few pieces of half-baked bread, Moro exceeded expectations for food, atmosphere, and service. With a long "tapas" bar stretching from the door, funky music, and an audible buzz - Moro feels trendy from the get-go; the kitchen, however, also seems to put considerable emphasis on fresh ingredients and delicious pairings. Loin of Lamb, served with an Okra/Chickpea Ratatouille was fantastic - and I heard similar exclamations/nods of approval from those around me, who were devouring everything from deep fried snails, to pork belly, to a sumptuous looking crab ragout on toast. Service was quick and friendly... no complaints here.Moro boasts a deep, Iberian-concentrated wine list - and a huge selection of sweet and dry sherries. If just looking for a nibble, there are a dozen smaller dishes available to eat at the bar.

uX4C6wCMp5MaaCFvqzjaWA.text: Finally tried Moro last night, on one of London's warmest days!  It was great to sit outside and enjoy the scene of Exmouth market, whilst trying to avoid the betting centre across the way and the accompanying crazies.We actually just had a bevy of tapas (even though technically you have to order a main per person if you're not sitting at the bar but they let it slide).  The mains around us looked FAB and I wish we tried some...next time.  I loved the paquillo peppers, patatas bravas, babaganoush, pickled peppers (a foot long each, no joke) and the tortillas!  The manchengo cheese with chutney wasn't great (not their fault?) nor was the chocolate and apricot tart that was served with something similar to sour cream...The sherry and wine list was extensive, and they also have a couple good token beers and cocktails.I will definitely go back, but I think Exmouth market it self needs to be cleaned up a bit- it can get a bit grimy.  Moro succeeds here, and would do very well in better parts of town.  Well done.  Looking forward to trying out the more casual version next door--looks just like a place you would find in New York!

tUhJOaxG7E4SB0OxkMSbUw.text: I first learned about Moro while working at a retreat center in Mallorca.  The chef made a lot of beautiful dishes from one of their cookbooks-- the leek yoghurt soup, the turla turla . . . that cookbook is the kind of book that makes you excited about cooking.  I would read it until WAY too late at night, and then go to sleep super pumped about green beans with yoghurt, garlic, and cinnamon.  So when I went back to London, I had to eat at Moro.  The tube station nearest to the restaurant was closed, so I got off at Liverpool Street Station and wandered around Smithfields for a while . . . long story.  But after a very long walk in the humid heat of that unseasonably warm spring, I arrived at Moro hungry and thirsty.The meal was impeccable.  The service, even though it was super crowded, was quick, efficient, friendly, and expert.I have posted pictures of my food to my blog: foodsexlit.com

5LTqaE_xTCsB46iGNjUkeA.text: I was first introduced to Moro when I worked nearby in Clerkenwell. Lucky it was payday Friday when went we for a long lunch because it's not cheap. The tapas were amazing and the staff even recommended which wine compliment our food. Probably not a good idea when we had to return to the office but it would have been rude to not try the barman's suggestions. Just over an hour we left Moro's trying to decide when we'd be back. I was the first to return a week later for dinner with my boyfriend. He's a real foodie and was very impressed with how good the food was. We both had thechargrilled lamb with chickpea puree and it was so good nothing was left on my plate. Not something I usually do!Everyone I've told about Moro's has loved it and you're crazy if you don't.

photos.caption: Photo of Moro Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Moro Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Moro Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

ycknR-WdE-IecjnPPXU5sw.text: I want to take this hummus and rub my face in it. Rub my face in it so my eyes sting, but I tell you, I'll still be smiling. For this is the hummus of kings, well Duchesses according to my brand spanking new iPhone app.After over a year of hankering I finally made it. I was a little suprised to see that this wasn't just tapas, actually, for me it was a little more Turkish than anything else. This was however, damn tasty. It was tittering on a 5 star experience. I mean, the poor waitress had to put up with a barrage of questions about the menu from me so you can see why she was a little surly. The food, was wonderful. And if you are a wine fun, then this is a must in London. Their wine list is longer than the last Harry Potter book and you can even get a selection of dessert wines to sample. The crowd here are older though, not really with families but well established couples and older groups of friends. It all adds to the mature grown-up vibe I get from this place. It also has a nice selection of out door seats. Just perfect for dinner on a warm summers day.

E-9jL86LSY4mt8AB0PAkog.text: The first time I tried to book a table at Moro, I underestimated how popular it is. I called on the Monday hoping for a Friday night slot. Nope, none left. How about the Saturday? No, that's full too. This process went on for a while and eventually I found myself booking a table for two weeks in the future. When the day finally came round I wasn't sure if I was in the mood for Mediterranean/ North African fare, maybe I'd just like a bag of chips from the shop instead? How stupid I was. This was one of the best meals I've ever had and I would wait months if that was what it took to get another table here. To start we shared a Harissa Squid Salad. This was no chewy calamari affair rather a sweet, smokey delicious piece of well cooked seafood. I loved it. Our mains were equally delicious especially my Lamb with Chickpea puree. As these dishes demonstrate the menu is very creative and applies spices and techniques more readily associated with Morocco to ingredients from the Med. Cooking this clever doesn't come cheap and our meal for two cost around £70. However, everything from the service to the wine was so perfect I have nothing to fault Moro for. If you're on a tighter budget I've heard that their bar tapas menu is also great. Highly recommended!

photos.caption: Photo of Moro Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

OIB6dFjRMKsL1tgOQGlTbw.text: I've read. I've pined. I've attempted. I've craved. I've done the walk-by more times than I'd like to admit. And last night, on London's most warm and glorious evening of the year, I finally sampled what all the Moro fuss is about. The Fuss:The ambiance helps... the food is as beautiful as the venue is as beautiful as the servers is as beautiful as the sun setting on Exmouth Market, revealing almost a Greek-like pleasure-filled, bustling alleyway. Not a bad way to dine, eh? The fresh bread immediately comes chunky, fluffy and freshly floured. The vegetarian mezze was a colourful splattering of various Spanish bits, and the fish and lamb were both perfectly charred outside and pink in the middle. All very very good things. But it's the wine that really stood out to me. The menu was so robust that it even came with training wheels - a numbering system for those who don't know much about the grape escape. I ended the evening with a dessert flight that blew me away. Sure it's pricey. Sure it's been a buzzing hot spot for 12 years. Sure it's busy and sometimes that 'we're the shizz and we know it' attitude can come through the phone reservation people. (I tried to reserve and dine three previous dates before getting seated tonight.) But there is certainly a rational reason behind all of those things. Don't go for a humble bargain - go for an experience of opulent deliciousness. So without any shame in my pun, gimme some Moro!

FMvqC_Z-bTkwtaXA5GqdmQ.text: I absolutely love this place. I came here on a week evening with a friend and we had some delectable wine and tapas at the bar. The lady serving us was so sweet and friendly. I decided to try a few different things which is the joy of ordering tapas, so I had white asparagus, habas Fritas, grilled chorizo and some roast almonds with paprika all absolutely delicious. The evening was a memorable one for many reasons, the company, the food, the wine, the warm welcome. I cant wait to find an excuse to go back here.

photos.caption: Photo of Moro Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

uWVzW6WzaJ81AfUFJA1xgg.text: My boyfriend and I went to Moro a few months ago. We sat outside and had a glass of wine on the pavement first (even though it was October!) and then had a really delicious meal. The staff were super helpful and it definitely is worth asking their advice. I had THE most amazing starter of tender lamb and yoghurt. The food really is fantastic at Moro - nothing pretentious but everything very well flavoured and authentic. The atmosphere is great too - laid back, almost canteen style. Again, not the formality you might expect with such an award winning restaurant. Moro comes highly recommended - definitely one of the best restaurants in London.

UQ7FEDsCpXNMNEhKEmMPPQ.text: I brought my boyfriend here for his birthday and it was one of the best restaurants I've ever been to. The ambience was great and wasn't too loud even when we ate around seven. Our food was delivered in a timely manner and the water was refilled almost instantly after we ran out. Our waitress, Keren, was the BEST. She was extremely helpful when we asked questions about the menu, very attentive, and sweet. We tipped her generously and joked that we wanted her to be our best friend.Aside from the service, the food was wonderful. Even the sourdough bread that they put on the table was delicious. The vegetable mezze was by far the best vegetarian dish I've had. I highly recommend this restaurant for a treat or special occasion as it is a bit pricey. But it was worth it!

OHsXuChY0OjqdrW0ZetcVg.text: Quite simply, fabulous in every way. 10 reasons for said fabulosity:1. Called Monday morning, got a table for 9:15pm that night. 2. Arrived early, were sat right away. 3. Great wine list, mostly Spanish. Big range of prices, helpful descriptive numbering system and very good wine for reasonable prices. 4. Fantastic dense, chewy sourdough bread and olive oil for every table. 5. Friendly, funny, easygoing server who helped us wade through the menu and gave helpful, sincere suggestions on how to maximize menu enjoyment while still saving room for dessert. 6. The aubergine and yogurt salad/dip/plate of amazing with crispy lamb and little pita cracker bites of crunch. Smooth, velvety, toasty, wow. 7. The pork with green churrasco sauce. Fatty melt-in-your-mouth perfection. 8. The lamb. Pink and phenomenal. 9. The dessert. This famous yogurt cake looks like baby vomit on a plate. It is also one of the best desserts I have ever had. Apparently ours was the 'last of the cake' so it didn't quite have the form that the others have, and so they gave it to us on the house. My friend licked the plate clean. I'm not even kidding.10. We bought two cookbooks. That should tell you how good the food was and how much we wanted the experience to continue. A week later and I've already made three dishes from it. Slam dunk five stars for Moro. Go go go.

_0z_2uChh1wl7Q_sr0vVEw.text: I love the food here, and the unpretentious laid back ambience. Service has always been very good. It's one of my favourite places in London to eat out if I want something special.

s9De8YWHtbVkiaKMn0s-9Q.text: Having just read Thomas W's review of Moro I feel much the same. I had been looking forward to dining here for some time, having enjoyed reading Nigel Slater's review in the Oberver Food Monthly. The whole experience however, was underwhelming, and very disappointing. I asked myself: How could such a restaurant garner such incredible reviews?The restaurant was pretty full and there are a lot of tables so I felt a little cramped, especially with the large coat stand towering over me, which seems to swamp the dining room.Starters of Braised chard and Jamon and Artichoke Soup were ok, but actually getting someone to serve us was proving to be difficult. Main courses of Chicken and Lamb were reasonably tasty, but my aubergine was incredibly over seasoned.At which point a table towards the bar was becoming increasingly rowdy, men were arguing, and when a member of staff asked them to quieten down, they looked prepared for a fight!Perhaps my expectations were too high, but I left with a feeling that this restaurant is horribly overhyped. I've had better food in local pubs, let alone other restaurants in similar price bracket to Moro. Why is it that Guardian reading Islington types love it so much?  Can someone please tell me?

oHdgaD9_O0HbSCfEPBIwvQ.text: My favourite spot in Moro is a stool at the bar, have had diner in the main restaurant many times but I think that eating at the zinc counter is by far the best experience. Go at the end of the luchtime rush and you get all the vibe with none of the chaos. Top tip is that you can extend your menu choice by ordering startes or deserts from the main menu if you ask nicely!! House wine went down very well at £14 and they have a great choice of sherry. Chorizo salad with beans was sublime. Tortilla was firm, moist and full of flavour. Plenty of bread on the bar with good olive oil!! Cheese to finish was a great selection and had been treated well. 9/10 Great food, wine and an excellent place to watch the world go by.

B6cZ3dCVlL-f9WlXWzSmrg.text: I know I've given Moro 5 stars , but I have to be honest with you when I write that I was not in a 5-star place when the bf and I went here on Saturday. I'm coming down with the lurgy and he's just getting over it, so the bottle of wine and heaps of tapas that I envisioned us consuming did not happen. Instead we had a quiet, somewhat leisurely but mostly sober Saturday afternoon lunch. I had a whole sea bream with cauliflower and chick pea side which was fantastic and the bf had lamb. My starter of salt cod with roasted red peppers was fantastic and my one glass of dry but fruity white was easy to drink. I would go back in a heartbeat when I am feeling better and I'm picking up one of their cookbooks soon - if that's any indication of how I feel about the place.

Ufq9LhFasGLwveorv4dTkg.text: I have been avoiding writing a review of Moro because it can't say what I want it to say. I want to say the food was thrilling. I want to say it was inventive, brilliant, complex. I want to revel in its neighbourhood vibe and its relaxed ambiance. Unfortunately it turned out to be another over hyped restaurant. I have wanted to go to Moro forever. I have never been organised enough to book. I will ring up on a Monday and ask for a table for two that night, they will say how about next week. This has been going on for years and is a testament to their popularity. I finally went the other week for a big meet the parents meal. The vibe is nice, buzzy and interested. The waiters were, given how stuffed the restaurant was, understandably busy. The forgetfulness was fine, the edge of rudeness or just get on with it was not. What I was excited about was the food. This is what Moro is about. Unfortunately what it was was pairings which didn't work, or where one sauce overpowered another. For instance my fish was completely overpowered by an aioli which I spent the first couple of minutes removing like a contagion. The other dishes were fine, not quite there, with an ingredient or taste that normally didn't quite fit. I wouldn't say the meal was bad and the bread for a starter was great. It was just distinctly underwhelming and the thing about Moro is that for all its friendly chummy neighbourhood vibe it is charging premium prices. For that it should be better.

XR8zc0Qkx6kfkIdPpAohPA.text: Very nice restaurant and delicious food. I took the lamb meal. Also starter the peppers and babaganoug.

Z_kBlLTyQ6TAYZw6NXxG-Q.text: Really disappointing dinner - food was nothing to go back for. Service was poor; albeit the waitress was polite, they gave us wrong wines twice (which they charged us double for) and did not know the english translation of the dishes on the menu. Not just overpriced but down right bad. Surprised by how others rated this place - only explanation has to be the menu varying per season. I would advise to go only if you have to but do not initiate it yourself.Bread - probably the best part of the meal. The bread was fresh and of good quality. Served with decent olive oil and salt/pepper seasoningKale salad (starter) - tiny portion of weirdly seasoned kale, served with a fresh but odd tasting cheese (avoid)Chicharrón with hummus (starter) - nothing special. Taste was plain, deep fried tiny portion served on a bed of humus (edible but not good)Plaice (main) - this was good. Vegetables accompanying the fish were very tasty (mainly tomato, parsley and cucumber) and the fish seemed fresh (be careful of the bones but otherwise order)

HmMQQuQJRdhwfg85nN3z1g.text: £350 dinner, dry rabbit, jamon claiming to be pata negra but absolutely wasn't, watermelon salad with the large seeds (just lazy), mains that were over complicated, rude service and best of all A MOUSE RUNNING ACROSS THW FLOOR FOR DESSERT!! The best part were the espresso martinis and the pork belly. Wayyy too many amazing Spanish restaurants in this city to waste your time and money here!!

EIcvjJ6hiZXa64_vW5o7EQ.text: Definitely check this place out.  The lamacun (with lamb sweetbreads) and veggie mezze were my favorites.  Locals abounded during my visit - servers appeared to know diners.

F0ypqaKViFAwwx-x4YgjcQ.text: Came here for a late lunch on a Monday. Apparently they only sell the tapas menu if you sit at the bar, but it was so not crowded that they let us order tapas from a table.The waiter recommended around 3-5 tapas per person, but we ended up getting 5 total for both of us: chicken wings, patatas bravas, baba ganoush, grilled chorizos, and mojama with peppers. They were all good! The patatas had the most generous portion, with a (small) plate overflowing with potato cubes. The grilled chicken wings turned out to be 2 wings and 2 drumsticks, which was perfect.The cardamom ice cream and the raisin ice cream we ordered for dessert were both very exotic, in a good way.Ended up being around £22 per person for lunch - a bit too pricey for me to frequent, so maybe I'll try their stall in the market next time :)

photos.caption: Photo of Moro Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Ice cream for dessert!

SBK1WmBTwrosKkgGEDdk0w.text: Really enjoyed this dining experience, the food and service fantastic - a choice I was very happy to make. Ok so the restaurant was a bit more formal than I was expecting, I was hoping that with it being Basque with a hint of North African it would be more authentic and chilled out, but this wasn't a problem, just not what I was expecting! The wild boar pork bely was fantastic, perfectly cooked and the potatoes that went alongside it were some that I wish I could eat every day - so so nice!They had a good selection of craft beers and wine, I was tempted by the sherry flights they also do but couldn't really pair it up with my choice of dessert so decided to hold on for a beer at the next bar. And on the note of pudding - yoghurt cake FTW - so good!

photos.caption: Photo of Moro Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Yoghurt cake
Photo of Moro Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Wild boar with Seville oranges

ISXEZUhoGlLbiaiWWVIHhg.text: I had been waiting to try Moro having heard so much about it. We went on a Friday for lunch and it was a rare beautiful sunny day in London. The restaurant was very handsome and I very much appreciated the spare decor by thinking they would instead highlight the food. The ambience and crowd seemed just right and we were primed for a great dining experience. Unfortunately that didn't happen and we left disappointed. For our appetizer we shared the grilled Octopus with chick pea puree - that was outstanding but it was all downhill from there. The Branzino I had was under-seasoned and there was really nothing tasty about it. It was  cooked perfectly but peculiarly under-seasoned for a restaurant that specializes in Moorish/Spanish/Turkish food. There was no subtlety to the seasonings - it just wasn't tasty. My friend had the wood roasted chicken which was good but on the dry side. Again, nothing to write home about. The most disappointing by far was the dessert. We got the chocolate ganache cake with yogurt. I thought they meant the cake was made with yogurt which sounded intriguing. But it was a slice of rich chocolate cake with a few spoons of plain yogurt for a sauce next to it. The idea was to mix the plain, slightly sour yogurt with the chocolate cake. We were told the yogurt was house -made but the juxtapositioning  of the 2 was completely off. Who thought this would be a good pairing? Overall, nothing to recommend here except the bread they serve initially with some great olive oil and the grilled octopus. Would not return.

wT-ob7XNMOL6Rt0MTB8P8A.text: My friend organized her birthday dinner here last weekend, and while I have been to its little sister Morito next door, I have never made it to the original, legendary Moro. I'd always thought of it as posh fine dining, but I think I was quite wrong - it's not even white tablecloth. We had a table off to the back and shared the room with just one other group, which was a very nice touch for a special occasion dinner. The vibe feels similar to that of Social Eating House - it's happening, it's busy, it's not over the top posh or formal, but the food is incredible.I ordered the seared venison as a starter and the charcoal grilled lamb as a main. Normally I would have thought the two would be a bit heavy in combination, but they were by far the ones that called to me. The meat was incredibly flavourful without being too rich. I especially liked the dried pepper salsa that came with the lamb, and it was a great pairing that differentiated the meat from a roast that you can get anywhere else. I'd definitely come again for a solid, hearty meal that looks great and doesn't break the bank.

YvHEnQ2ZjQFmEWfCfB5g_w.text: Delicious food and creative menu!  I ordered the cod and it was very nice. My coworker ordered the artichoke starter and it was very good. Will be back.

J-h2zUTdFe5tZlhWOGaXWg.text: Consistently excellent with a great changing menu makes it a great place to visit as often as possible as you're never going top be bored with the unusual flavours. The wine list is always keeps me coming back for more with full of unusual offerings at decent prices and the atmosphere is very buzzy...which is what I ALWAYS love. I would go her for all occasions.

Wh0jiBKeRA02FVAsaI8Pqw.text: My favorite go to restaurant whenever I travel to London. I can eat here all the time. It has the balance of everything - cozy, intimate, busy and above all delicious food !!

3ODbl4EErwv31RzOZQxS3g.text: OK, Five years later I eat in the proper restaurant.  The food was delicious!  I loved my fish and all of the food we had was great.  Service was a bit unfriendly.  But loved the atmosphere and the food.  (Although our rose was a tad warm as well).

5QY94Ghd-xJRPB8CNJLYZw.text: Moro is one of those places I've wanted to eat at for ages but haven't because I don't like having to reserve ages in advance so fortunately we were able to get a table for 9pm on a Friday evening with only a few days notice.It was great. Inside it's buzzing with a simple, open layout and open kitchen at the end. A long bar extends the entire length of the restaurant (taps menu only available at the bar).Ordered the mushrooms on toast for starter which was excellent. Simple and with balanced flavours. They could have given the dish a fancy name with some unfamiliar funghi name on  char grilled crispy sourdough bread with olive oil from some single estate in Spain (which it all may well have been) but credit to them that they just called it 'mushrooms on toast'. Sometimes pretentious menu descriptions fail to deliver when the actual dish shows up but in this case it was the other way round.For mains I ordered chargrilled lamb with rice and some beetroot based sauce. That wasn't the actual menu description but just my memory of what I ate. The waitress mentioned the lamb would be served pink and was that OK. Yes, no problem. This dish was just delicious. A generous serving of yes, very pink lamb slices on a bed of rice and some other grains which had been slow cooked with spices and something else which just made it great and a cold beetroot based  sauce over the top. Back to the lamb. It wasn't rare in the normal sense yet tender and flavourful. Perhaps it was cooked sous vide and then finished on the chargrill....However they did it, it was just excellent.For desert I opted for the Malaga raisin ice cream. So simple again and so good. What made it was the glass of sherry poured over with some giant raisins which may also have been sherry soaked. Yum.Service was efficient and food arrived pronto, yet no feeling of time pressure at all even though tables were turning around us with only minutes between the next diners being seated.I'm looking forward to going back.

1hNkB6GskIU8fHOnC3FfXQ.text: We love this restaurant and return here every time we visit London. This time we came back three times and ate almost every item on the menu. The best of the best were the fish and vegetable dishes. Specifically, the seared mackerel with rhubarb/tarragon/walnut salad was amazing - even my husband who doesn't like either mackerel or rhubarb, loved this dish.  He had the broad bean soup twice.  Two other starters not to be missed are the quail and the asparagus/oyster mushroom/jamon.  The sea bass main course was our favorite entree mostly because of the braised fennel, baked feta and salad of orange and pea salad that came with it - perfection. The Spanish wines recommended paired with the food were also excellent. Usually we are all about the food and not overly focused on the service but at Moro, the staff was not only good at their jobs but genuinely hospitable, even recognizing us on our second and third visits and welcoming us back. Finally, I can't thank Emma and her kitchen colleagues (including Sam) for taking such good care of us and answering my many questions about the preparation of their dishes. Their generosity enhanced our flavor filled dining experiences even more. Thanks Moro!

ZZ2N8FRonFQiRJsKvBq3cA.text: Not sure what the fuss is all about at Moro. Sure, I'm glad its in my neighbourhood as it has made Exmouth Market a serious foody destination. I've also bought the books and made some wonderful food but the core product, the restaurant, always disappoints. Firstly, whats with the menu? With all those exciting recipes in their three cookbooks the menu barely changes especially the main courses which heavily rely on the wood fired oven which tends to be a bit like russian roulette with the doneness of the meat. I have had overdone chicken and underdone pork. The more interesting tapas menu is only available if you eat at the bar which seems crazy even if you're spend is the same. Staff are a mixed back of eager and helpful with laid back and inattentive.Morito next door is more interesting and has a more varied menu.

_v46ohflSqlOs8BUKKqBBw.text: We had an excellent meal this evening; my sea trout was especially delicious.  Following by a wonderful chocolate tart with creme fraiche -- couldn't have been better.  Although on line they were officially booked, we showed up and were able to give us a table for four right away -- indicative of the pleasant, attentive, and unobtrusive service throughout.  A wonderful experience.  I hope to return soon!

lDCY7REFXLhY21UpoZkn2w.text: Delicious meal and friendly service. Reasonable wine list. Try the Malaga raisin ice cream.

K75VRsDTEjthpa_TfV9mEQ.text: A Spanish restaurant with hints of North African influence.  If you are looking for tapas or small plates, then do not go here.  The tapas are only available at the bar.  For the tapas, small plates thing, go next door.Our dishes were generally flavorful, but nothing that would make me run back.  We (2 of us) had the following:Starters:Snail salad with sausage -- okay, but not served warm enough.Sardines -- grilled sardines served with salad and harisa.  It was okay, but drenched in oil.Mains:Lamb -- a large plate that was less lamb and more sides.  The lamb was nicely served pink and flavorfulSea bream -- a nice piece of white-meat fish served in a fino sauce (sherry based).  While the fish was good, the purple broccoli with better.  But my side should not be better than the main.Dessert:Yogurt cake.  This is not a pleasant dessert to look at.  In fact, you may think something went terribly wrong.  But it was very good.  The yogurt was tangy and the cake parts underneath provided the right contrast in texture.

dU5NSrhpbp-R0IUEsW7LJQ.text: Aweful place. The food was terrible and service was even worse. Waiter suggested we get the signature dessert and it tasted like crap literally. Then he tricked us into thinking he would gave us something else instead when we voiced our opinion. But he charged us for everything at the end and laughed at us !! How rude. Never again.

tNkSu48w3B0-FH47mwNsAQ.text: I really can't make up my mind about this place. I keep returning (a good thing) but I often leave slightly disappointed (like tonight). There are lots of plus points - a lively atmosphere, good Spanish focused wine list and engaging knowledgeable staff. However, I feel a little too crammed in, to the point that navigating through the tables means knocking into other diners.The food is also a bit hit and miss. From the starters we chose baby onions on toast with cecina and gamba y patatas alinadas.  The former was delicious with caramelised onions and tender beef (albeit on slightly burnt toast).  The later was something of a disappointment with the predominant flavour being slightly vinegary onions.  Not good!From the main courses, we ordered from the wood oven. The lamb (ordered medium and served, at best, medium to well done) was tasty although some of the accompanying vegetables got slightly lost. For example, a date and parsnip salad seemed conspicuously absent of date. The wood pigeon was better - partially deboned which made it easy to eat and pleasant on the eye with excellent crispy skin. To finish, we enjoyed the Malaga raisin ice cream featuring giant raisins and a lovely silky texture and Moro's stellar Chocolate and Apricot Tart never fails to deliver. The pastry is super thin and crunchy. The apricot gives a good glug of flavour and the chocolate is a soft, almost souffle like topping.It almost makes me forget all that went before. However, weaving your way through the crowd brings it all back. Just far too annoying for a restaurant with these prices. I am sure I will be back, perhaps sitting outside at lunch on a Summer's day. However moving forwards I expect it's little neighbour, Morito, will get more of its business - more fun, better value and no need to make reservations.
